page.title: 15SUTTON OLD BUILDINGS
page.content: The part of Sutton in the block has the oldest buildings.High Street was the focus of Old Sutton.Craven House,facing up High St.,is one of the oldest houses being of late sixteenth or early seventeenth century origin.A house in King's Court,off High St.,and over 200 years old,has a large first floor room,used by James Sugden for woolcombing in the 1840's.The house has thick walls and a wide staircase. Several old properties adjoin "The Ellers",a steep,winding road leading from High St. up onto Sutton Moor.The name "Ellers" was spelt "Hellers" in 1851 and comes from the Norse word for alder trees.Sutton House was built by Richard Dixon in 1639 but today has an eighteenth century facade.Higher up, America Farm,probably takes it's name from "Merica Ben",a tenant who had travelled in the U.S.A. in the 1860's.
